Legal_Issue: Whether the Board's conclusion on state protection in Pakistan was patently unreasonable
Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, section 96-98; Convention relating to the Status of Refugees
Application_Facts: Applicant is a Shia convert from Pakistan who faced threats and violence due to religious conversion
Remedy_Requested: Overturning of the Board's denial of refugee status
Court_Ruling: Board's decision was not patently unreasonable
Defendant_Behavior: Immigration and Refugee Board denied refugee claim based on adequacy of state protection
Grounds_for_Claim: Well-founded fear of persecution due to religious conversion
Assessment_Factor: Effectiveness and meaningfulness of state protection against sectarian violence
Applicable_Legislation: Convention relating to the Status of Refugees
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review of administrative decision by the Federal Court
Review_Standard: Patently unreasonable standard applied to assess reasonableness of Board's decision
Credibility_Assessment: Not explicitly challenged; focus on documentary evidence interpretation
Evidence_Used: Documentary evidence on Pakistan’s efforts to combat sectarian violence
Legal_Provision_Cited: Section 97(1) of IRPA; Article 1A(2) of the Refugee Convention
Application_Basis: Fear of persecution due to religion and lack of effective state protection
Evidence_Assessed: Reports on government actions to protect religious minorities in Pakistan
Relief_Sought: Granting of refugee status and protection in Canada
Governing_Rule: A Convention refugee must have a well-founded fear of persecution and be unable to access effective state protection
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Applicant alleged insufficient evidentiary support for Board’s finding, but court found otherwise
Decisional_Body: Immigration and Refugee Board of Canada
Harm_Assessment: Risk of sectarian violence due to religious identity
Cause_Description: Applicant, a Shia convert in Pakistan, experienced threats and violence prompting flight to Canada
Evidence_Handling: Board relied on country condition reports; court deferred to Board's evidentiary choices
Evidence_Issues: Dispute over interpretation of documentary evidence regarding state protection efficacy
Residency_Compliance: Applicant entered Canada and made a refugee claim
Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court jurisdiction to conduct judicial review of IRB decisions
Evidence_Assessment: Board assessed state protection as meaningful despite imperfections
Decision_Rationale: Pakistan making serious efforts to protect citizens from sectarian violence; protection deemed effective enough to deny refugee status
Evidentiary_Issues: Applicant contested weight given to country reports, but court found Board’s reliance reasonable
